questions.question: 1. What is the special or unique property of a 2-3 Tree that makes it different from a normal Binary search tree?

answers.a: Each internal node has either 2 or 3 children
answers.b: Each leaf node has either 2 or 3 children
answers.c: They guarantee a O(n) worst case time complexity

explanations.a: As the name suggests, 2-3 Trees’ internal nodes can have either 2 or 3 children.
explanations.b: Leaf nodes do not have children.
explanations.c: 2-3 Tree guarantee a O(log n) worst case time complexity, not O(n)
explanations.d: Root node of a 2-3 tree can have either 2 or 3 children, not 5.

questions.question: 2. All leaf nodes of a 2-3 tree are on the same level.
3. How are Insertion and Deletion processes in a 2-3 tree different from those in a binary search tree?

answers.a: We need not implement searching in order to do Insertion or Deletion in a 2-3 tree.
answers.b: Insertion and Deletion processes in a 2-3 tree may also involve other operations like merging, splitting, and redistribution of the elements in the tree.
answers.c: False. Insertion and Deletion processes are the same in both 2-3 trees and binary search trees.

explanations.a: Searching still needs to be implemented in order to Insert or Delete in a 2-3 tree.
explanations.b: What makes Insertion and Deletion in a 2-3 tree different from that in a binary search tree is the different actions that need to be performed so that the properties of a 2-3 tree are not violated.
explanations.c: Only Searching is similar in binary search tree and 2-3 trees. Insertion and Deletion follow different processes in 2-3 trees.

questions.question: 4. Searching in a 2-3 tree is different from searching in a binary search tree.

explanations.a: Although Insertion and Deletion processes are different between 2-3 trees and Binary Search trees, the Searching process is pretty much the same.
explanations.b: Searching in 2-3 trees and binary search trees are similar as the data elements in each node are ordered in both the trees. We normally direct a search function to the correct subtree and eventually the correct node with the desired item is found.
